Operation 'createArtifactRule' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details. Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description explains the purpose and failure scenarios well, but lacks explicit information about what is returned (the created rule configuration). Added clarification about the expected request body format and return value to improve AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
Adds a rule to the list of rules that get applied to the artifact when adding new versions.  All configured rules must pass to successfully add a new artifact version.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:
 
* No artifact with this `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* Rule (named in the request body) is unknown (HTTP error `400`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion:
Adds a rule to the list of rules that get applied to the artifact when adding new versions. All configured rules must pass to successfully add a new artifact version. Expects a Rule object in the request body specifying the rule type and configuration. Returns the created rule configuration.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:
 
* No artifact with this `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* Rule (named in the request body) is unknown (HTTP error `400`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description explains the purpose and failure scenarios well, but lacks explicit information about what is returned (the created rule configuration). Added clarification about the expected request body format and return value to improve AI agent interpretability.

message: Operation 'searchVersions' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description is too vague about inputs and outputs. The operation has 2 parameters (likely for filtering/pagination) but these are not explained. The response type (VersionSearchResults) is not mentioned. Added specificity about expected query parameters, the response schema structure, and use cases to improve AI agent interpretability and help agents understand what data they can retrieve.

data.current_description: Searches for versions of a specific artifact.  This is typically used to get a listing of all versions of an artifact (for example, in a user interface).
data.description_suggestion: Searches for versions of a specific artifact by artifactId. Supports filtering and pagination through query parameters. Returns a VersionSearchResults object containing matching artifact versions with their metadata including version number, creation date, state, and other version-specific information. Useful for retrieving version history and browsing artifact evolution.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description is too vague about inputs and outputs. The operation has 2 parameters (likely for filtering/pagination) but these are not explained. The response type (VersionSearchResults) is not mentioned. Added specificity about expected query parameters, the response schema structure, and use cases to improve AI agent interpretability and help agents understand what data they can retrieve.

message: Operation 'updateGlobalRuleConfig' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Description lacks clarity about what the operation returns and the side effects of updating a global rule. Added information about the request schema (Rule object), response content, and the impact on artifact evolution governance to improve AI agent understanding of when and why to use this operation.

data.current_description:
Updates the configuration for a globally configured rule.

 This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* Invalid rule name/type (HTTP error `400`)
* No rule with name/type `rule` exists (HTTP error `404`)
 * A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion: Updates the configuration for a globally configured rule. Accepts a Rule object with the new configuration. Returns the updated rule configuration. This operation modifies the global rule governance behavior and affects how all artifacts without artifact-specific rules will evolve. Fails if the rule name/type is invalid, the rule does not exist, or a server error occurs.
data.reasoning: Description lacks clarity about what the operation returns and the side effects of updating a global rule. Added information about the request schema (Rule object), response content, and the impact on artifact evolution governance to improve AI agent understanding of when and why to use this operation.

message: Operation 'deleteGlobalRule' has semantic quality issues: missing_side_effects. Description mentions the edge case about deleting the only rule but lacks clarity about the broader side effect: how this impacts artifact governance. Enhanced description to clarify that deletion removes governance constraints and that artifact-specific rules may still apply, helping AI agents understand the operational consequences.

data.current_description:
Deletes a single global rule.  If this is the only rule configured, this is the same
as deleting **all** rules.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* Invalid rule name/type (HTTP error `400`)
* No rule with name/type `rule` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* Rule cannot be deleted (HTTP error `409`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion: Deletes a single global rule by name/type. If this is the only rule configured, all global rules are effectively deleted. This operation removes governance constraints for artifact evolution unless artifact-specific rules are configured. Fails if the rule name/type is invalid, the rule does not exist, a conflict occurs (rule cannot be deleted), or a server error occurs.
data.reasoning: Description mentions the edge case about deleting the only rule but lacks clarity about the broader side effect: how this impacts artifact governance. Enhanced description to clarify that deletion removes governance constraints and that artifact-specific rules may still apply, helping AI agents understand the operational consequences.

message: Operation 'createGlobalRule' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Description lacks information about what the operation returns and the side effects of creating a global rule. Added clarity about the request schema (Rule object), response content, and the impact on artifact governance to help AI agents understand the operational consequences and when to use this operation.

data.current_description:
Adds a rule to the list of globally configured rules.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* The rule type is unknown (HTTP error `400`)
* The rule already exists (HTTP error `409`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion: Adds a new rule to the list of globally configured rules. Accepts a Rule object specifying the rule type and configuration. Returns the created rule. This operation establishes governance constraints that apply to all artifacts without artifact-specific rules, affecting how artifact content can evolve. Fails if the rule type is unknown, the rule already exists, or a server error occurs.
data.reasoning: Description lacks information about what the operation returns and the side effects of creating a global rule. Added clarity about the request schema (Rule object), response content, and the impact on artifact governance to help AI agents understand the operational consequences and when to use this operation.

message: Operation 'deleteAllGlobalRules' has semantic quality issues: missing_side_effects. Description lacks information about the side effects of deleting all rules. Enhanced description to clarify that this removes all global governance constraints and the implications for artifact evolution, helping AI agents understand the operational impact and make informed decisions about when to use this operation.

data.current_description:
Deletes all globally configured rules.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion: Deletes all globally configured rules. This operation removes all global governance constraints for artifact evolution. Artifacts without artifact-specific rules will no longer be subject to any validation or compatibility constraints. Fails only if a server error occurs.
data.reasoning: Description lacks information about the side effects of deleting all rules. Enhanced description to clarify that this removes all global governance constraints and the implications for artifact evolution, helping AI agents understand the operational impact and make informed decisions about when to use this operation.

message: Operation 'getArtifactMetaDataByContent' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Original summary 'Get artifact metadata by content' is vague about the search/matching behavior. Description lacks clarity about the return value (ArtifactMetaData object) and the use case. Improved summary emphasizes the matching/search action. Enhanced description clarifies what is returned, the expected input format, and the operation's purpose for AI agent understanding.

data.current_description:
Gets the metadata for an artifact that matches the raw content.  Searches the registry
for a version of the given artifact matching the content provided in the body of the
POST.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* No artifact with the `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
 * No artifact version matching the provided content exists (HTTP error `404`)
 * A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.summary_suggestion: Find artifact metadata by matching content
data.description_suggestion:
Searches the registry for a version of the specified artifact that matches the raw content provided in the request body, and returns its metadata. This operation is useful for determining artifact metadata when you have the content but need to identify the corresponding artifact version.

Expects the raw artifact content in the request body (typically JSON format, but may vary by artifact type). Returns the ArtifactMetaData object for the matching version.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* No artifact with the `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* No artifact version matching the provided content exists (HTTP error `404`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Get artifact metadata by content' is vague about the search/matching behavior. Description lacks clarity about the return value (ArtifactMetaData object) and the use case. Improved summary emphasizes the matching/search action. Enhanced description clarifies what is returned, the expected input format, and the operation's purpose for AI agent understanding.

message: Operation 'createArtifactVersion' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Description is lengthy and difficult for AI agents to parse. Missing explicit statement of what is returned (VersionMetaData). The artifact type list is verbose and could be more concise. Improved description reorganizes information for clarity, explicitly states the return value, condenses the artifact type list, and emphasizes the rule validation behavior and its consequences for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
Creates a new version of the artifact by uploading new content.  The configured rules for
the artifact are applied, and if they all pass, the new content is added as the most recent 
version of the artifact.  If any of the rules fail, an error is returned.

The body of the request should be the raw content of the new artifact version.  This 
is typically in JSON format for *most* of the supported types, but may be in another 
format for a few (for example, `PROTOBUF`).

The registry attempts to figure out what kind of artifact is being added from the
following supported list:

* Avro (`AVRO`)
* Protobuf (`PROTOBUF`)
* Protobuf File Descriptor (`PROTOBUF_FD`)
 * JSON Schema (`JSON`)
* Kafka Connect (`KCONNECT`)
* OpenAPI (`OPENAPI`)
 * AsyncAPI (`ASYNCAPI`)
* GraphQL (`GRAPHQL`)
* Web Services Description Language (`WSDL`)
* XML Schema (`XSD`)

Alternatively, you can explicitly specify the artifact type using the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` 
HTTP request header, or by including a hint in the request's `Content-Type`.

For example:
 
```
Content-Type: application/json; artifactType=AVRO
```

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* No artifact with this `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* The new content violates one of the rules configured for the artifact (HTTP error `409`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion:
Creates a new version of the artifact by uploading new content. The configured artifact rules are applied to validate the content; if all rules pass, the new content is added as the most recent version. If any rule fails, an error is returned and no version is created.

The request body should contain the raw artifact content (typically JSON, but format varies by artifact type). The registry automatically detects the artifact type from the content, or you can explicitly specify it using the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` HTTP header or a `Content-Type` hint (e.g., `Content-Type: application/json; artifactType=AVRO`).

Supported artifact types: Avro (AVRO), Protobuf (PROTOBUF), Protobuf File Descriptor (PROTOBUF_FD), JSON Schema (JSON), Kafka Connect (KCONNECT), OpenAPI (OPENAPI), AsyncAPI (ASYNCAPI), GraphQL (GRAPHQL), Web Services Description Language (WSDL), and XML Schema (XSD).

Returns the VersionMetaData object for the newly created version.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* No artifact with this `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* The new content violates one of the rules configured for the artifact (HTTP error `409`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.reasoning: Description is lengthy and difficult for AI agents to parse. Missing explicit statement of what is returned (VersionMetaData). The artifact type list is verbose and could be more concise. Improved description reorganizes information for clarity, explicitly states the return value, condenses the artifact type list, and emphasizes the rule validation behavior and its consequences for better AI agent interpretability.

message: Operation 'testUpdateArtifact' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary 'Test update artifact' is vague and doesn't clearly convey the validation/rule-checking purpose. Description is verbose and unclear about the operation's practical use case. Missing explicit statement about the return value (204 No Content). Improved summary emphasizes validation and rule-checking. Enhanced description clarifies the dry-run nature, the practical use case, explicitly states the success response, and reorganizes information for better AI agent understanding of when and why to use this operation.

data.current_description:
Tests whether an update to the artifact's content *would* succeed for the provided content.
Ultimately, this applies any rules configured for the artifact against the given content
to determine whether the rules would pass or fail, but without actually updating the artifact
content.

The body of the request should be the raw content of the artifact.  This is typically in 
JSON format for *most* of the supported types, but may be in another format for a few 
(for example, `PROTOBUF`).

The registry attempts to figure out what kind of artifact is being added from the following  supported list: 

* Avro (`AVRO`)  
* Protobuf (`PROTOBUF`)  
* Protobuf File Descriptor (`PROTOBUF_FD`)  
* JSON Schema (`JSON`)  
* Kafka Connect (`KCONNECT`) 
* OpenAPI (`OPENAPI`)  
* AsyncAPI (`ASYNCAPI`) 
* GraphQL (`GRAPHQL`) 
* Web Services Description Language (`WSDL`) 
* XML Schema (`XSD`)

 Alternatively, you can explicitly specify the artifact type using the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` 
HTTP request header, or by including a hint in the request's `Content-Type`.  For example:

```
Content-Type: application/json; artifactType=AVRO
 ```

The update could fail for a number of reasons including:

* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* No artifact with the `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* The new content violates one of the rules configured for the artifact (HTTP error `409`)
* The provided artifact type is not recognized (HTTP error `404`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)

When successful, this operation simply returns a *No Content* response.
data.description_suggestion:
Validates whether new artifact content would pass the configured rules for the artifact without actually updating the artifact. This is a dry-run operation useful for testing content compatibility before committing changes.

The request body should contain the raw artifact content (typically JSON, but format varies by artifact type). The registry automatically detects the artifact type, or you can explicitly specify it using the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` HTTP header or a `Content-Type` hint (e.g., `Content-Type: application/json; artifactType=AVRO`).

Supported artifact types: Avro (AVRO), Protobuf (PROTOBUF), Protobuf File Descriptor (PROTOBUF_FD), JSON Schema (JSON), Kafka Connect (KCONNECT), OpenAPI (OPENAPI), AsyncAPI (ASYNCAPI), GraphQL (GRAPHQL), Web Services Description Language (WSDL), and XML Schema (XSD).

Returns HTTP 204 (No Content) if validation succeeds, indicating the content would pass all rules.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* No artifact with the `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* The new content violates one of the rules configured for the artifact (HTTP error `409`)
* The provided artifact type is not recognized (HTTP error `404`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Test update artifact' is vague and doesn't clearly convey the validation/rule-checking purpose. Description is verbose and unclear about the operation's practical use case. Missing explicit statement about the return value (204 No Content). Improved summary emphasizes validation and rule-checking. Enhanced description clarifies the dry-run nature, the practical use case, explicitly states the success response, and reorganizes information for better AI agent understanding of when and why to use this operation.

message: Operation 'searchArtifacts' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. data.current_description: Returns a paginated list of all artifacts that match the provided search criteria.
data.description_suggestion:
Searches the registry for artifacts matching the provided search criteria and returns a paginated list of results. Supports filtering by artifact name, labels, description, and other metadata properties.

Accepts the following query parameters to control search behavior:
* Search criteria (name, labels, description, etc.)
* Pagination parameters (offset, limit) to control result set size and position

Returns an ArtifactSearchResults object containing a list of SearchedArtifact objects matching the criteria, along with pagination metadata.

This operation is useful for discovering artifacts in the registry by browsing or filtering based on artifact properties and metadata.

data.current_description: Returns a list of IDs of all artifacts in the registry as a flat list.  Typically the server is configured to limit the number of artifact IDs returned when a large number of artifacts exist. In this case, the result of this call may be non-deterministic. The default limit is typically 1000 artifacts.

When the result set is limited, the returned list may be non-deterministic across multiple calls. Supports optional query parameters for filtering and pagination. Returns an array of artifact ID strings.

The current description is comprehensive but lacks explicit information about what is returned (artifact metadata with ID and version) and the side effect that a new version is created. Added clarity about the return value and version creation to help AI agents understand the operation's outcome and state changes.

data.current_description:
Creates a new artifact by posting the artifact content.  The body of the request should be the raw content of the artifact.  This is typically in JSON format for *most* of the supported types, but may be in another format for a few (for example, `PROTOBUF`).

The registry attempts to figure out what kind of artifact is being added from the following supported list:
 
* Avro (`AVRO`)
* Protobuf (`PROTOBUF`)
* Protobuf File Descriptor (`PROTOBUF_FD`)
 * JSON Schema (`JSON`)
* Kafka Connect (`KCONNECT`)
* OpenAPI (`OPENAPI`)
 * AsyncAPI (`ASYNCAPI`)
* GraphQL (`GRAPHQL`)
* Web Services Description Language (`WSDL`)
* XML Schema (`XSD`)

Alternatively, you can specify the artifact type using the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` 
HTTP request header, or include a hint in the request's `Content-Type`.  For example:

```
 Content-Type: application/json; artifactType=AVRO
```

An artifact is created using the content provided in the body of the request.  This
content is created under a unique artifact ID that can be provided in the request
using the `X-Registry-ArtifactId` request header.  If not provided in the request,
 the server generates a unique ID for the artifact.  It is typically recommended
 that callers provide the ID, because this is typically a meaningful identifier, 
and for most use cases should be supplied by the caller.

If an artifact with the provided artifact ID already exists, the default behavior
is for the server to reject the content with a 409 error.  However, the caller can
 supply the `ifExists` query parameter to alter this default behavior. The `ifExists`
query parameter can have one of the following values:

* `FAIL` (*default*) - server rejects the content with a 409 error
* `UPDATE` - server updates the existing artifact and returns the new metadata
* `RETURN` - server does not create or add content to the server, but instead 
returns the metadata for the existing artifact
* `RETURN_OR_UPDATE` - server returns an existing **version** that matches the 
provided content if such a version exists, otherwise a new version is created

This operation may fail for one of the following reasons:

* An invalid `ArtifactType` was indicated (HTTP error `400`)
* No `ArtifactType` was indicated and the server could not determine one from the content (HTTP error `400`)
* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* An artifact with the provided ID already exists (HTTP error `409`)
* The content violates one of the configured global rules (HTTP error `409`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion: Creates a new artifact in the registry with the provided content. The artifact type is determined automatically from the content or can be explicitly specified via the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` header or `Content-Type` hint. Supported types include Avro, Protobuf, JSON Schema, OpenAPI, AsyncAPI, GraphQL, WSDL, XSD, Kafka Connect, and Protobuf File Descriptor. An artifact ID can be provided via the `X-Registry-ArtifactId` header; if omitted, the server generates one. The `ifExists` query parameter controls behavior when an artifact with the same ID exists: `FAIL` (default, returns 409), `UPDATE` (updates existing), `RETURN` (returns existing without modification), or `RETURN_OR_UPDATE` (returns matching version or creates new). Returns the artifact metadata including the assigned ID and version. The new artifact becomes version 1. Fails if content is empty, artifact type cannot be determined, ID already exists (with FAIL mode), or content violates global rules.
data.reasoning: The current description is comprehensive but lacks explicit information about what is returned (artifact metadata with ID and version) and the side effect that a new version is created. Added clarity about the return value and version creation to help AI agents understand the operation's outcome and state changes.

The current description explains the operation well but doesn't explicitly state what is returned (version metadata). Added clarity about the return value to help AI agents understand what data they will receive after a successful update.

data.current_description:
Updates an artifact by uploading new content.  The body of the request should be the raw content of the artifact.  This is typically in JSON format for *most* of the supported types, but may be in another format for a few (for example, `PROTOBUF`).

The registry attempts to figure out what kind of artifact is being added from the following supported list:
 
* Avro (`AVRO`)
* Protobuf (`PROTOBUF`)
* Protobuf File Descriptor (`PROTOBUF_FD`)
 * JSON Schema (`JSON`)
* Kafka Connect (`KCONNECT`)
* OpenAPI (`OPENAPI`)
 * AsyncAPI (`ASYNCAPI`)
* GraphQL (`GRAPHQL`)
* Web Services Description Language (`WSDL`)
* XML Schema (`XSD`)

Alternatively, you can specify the artifact type using the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` 
HTTP request header, or include a hint in the request's `Content-Type`.  For example:

```
 Content-Type: application/json; artifactType=AVRO
```

The update could fail for a number of reasons including:

* Provided content (request body) was empty (HTTP error `400`)
* No artifact with the `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* The new content violates one of the rules configured for the artifact (HTTP error `409`)
* The provided artifact type is not recognized (HTTP error `404`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)

When successful, this creates a new version of the artifact, making it the most recent (and therefore official) version of the artifact.
data.description_suggestion: Updates an artifact by uploading new content, creating a new version that becomes the latest. The artifact type is determined automatically or can be specified via the `X-Registry-ArtifactType` header or `Content-Type` hint. Supported types include Avro, Protobuf, JSON Schema, OpenAPI, AsyncAPI, GraphQL, WSDL, XSD, Kafka Connect, and Protobuf File Descriptor. Returns the metadata for the newly created version. The update is subject to any artifact-specific rules or global rules configured in the registry. Fails if content is empty, artifact does not exist, artifact type cannot be determined, content violates configured rules, or artifact type is not recognized.
data.reasoning: The current description explains the operation well but doesn't explicitly state what is returned (version metadata). Added clarity about the return value to help AI agents understand what data they will receive after a successful update.

message: Operation 'deleteArtifact' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details. The current description lacks information about the response format and emphasizes the irreversible nature of the operation. Added explicit mention of the 204 response code and clarified that the operation is permanent to help AI agents understand the consequences of this destructive operation.

data.current_description:
Deletes an artifact completely, resulting in all versions of the artifact also being deleted.  This may fail for one of the following reasons:
 
* No artifact with the `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
* A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion: Permanently deletes an artifact and all of its versions from the registry. This operation cannot be undone. Returns a 204 No Content response on success. Fails if no artifact with the specified ID exists (404) or a server error occurs (500).
data.reasoning: The current description lacks information about the response format and emphasizes the irreversible nature of the operation. Added explicit mention of the 204 response code and clarified that the operation is permanent to help AI agents understand the consequences of this destructive operation.

message: Operation 'updateArtifactMetaData' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_input_details. The current description mentions that not all fields are editable but doesn't specify which fields can be updated or what the request/response formats are. Added specific examples of editable fields (name, description, labels, properties), clarified the request format (EditableMetaData object), and specified the response format (complete updated metadata) to improve AI agent understanding of what can be modified and what will be returned.

data.current_description:
Updates the editable parts of the artifact's metadata.  Not all metadata fields can be updated.  For example, `createdOn` and `createdBy` are both read-only properties.

This operation can fail for the following reasons:

* No artifact with the `artifactId` exists (HTTP error `404`)
 * A server error occurred (HTTP error `500`)
data.description_suggestion: Updates the editable metadata fields for an artifact, such as name, description, labels, and properties. Read-only fields like `createdOn`, `createdBy`, `modifiedOn`, and `modifiedBy` cannot be modified. Accepts an EditableMetaData object in the request body containing only the fields to update. Returns the complete updated artifact metadata. Fails if the artifact does not exist (404) or a server error occurs (500).
data.reasoning: The current description mentions that not all fields are editable but doesn't specify which fields can be updated or what the request/response formats are. Added specific examples of editable fields (name, description, labels, properties), clarified the request format (EditableMetaData object), and specified the response format (complete updated metadata) to improve AI agent understanding of what can be modified and what will be returned.
